context: This subcomponent implements specialized mechanisms and architectures that restrict AI system capabilities and access to the external environment, establishing secure boundaries that prevent potentially misaligned AI from operating outside intended parameters.
name: Containment Systems

items.description: Containment systems provide specifications to verify while formal verification provides mathematical guarantees about containment system effectiveness
Containment systems provide infrastructure for fail-safe responses while fail-safe mechanisms detect and respond to containment violations
Containment systems implement core aspects of safety layer architectures, particularly boundary enforcement and isolation patterns
Containment systems provide boundary status and violation data to monitoring systems, which provide context for adaptive containment measures
Mechanistic interpretability techniques support containment by identifying potential boundary violations, while containment systems provide secure environments for interpretation

literature_connections.relevant_aspects: Orseau & Armstrong provide theoretical foundations for containment of AI systems through the lens of interruptibility, with direct applications to secure execution environments and virtualization techniques
Amodei et al. identify concrete safety problems that capability control mechanisms can address, particularly in preventing unintended AI behaviors through limited and graduated capability release
Critch & Krueger's work on compartmentalized AI directly informs the design of information barrier systems, notably in how to create secure information flow controls between AI system components
Hendrycks et al. provide an extensive analysis of unsolved safety problems that capability control mechanisms must address, including emergent capabilities and capability amplification risks

Leike et al.'s work on containment through gridworlds provides a conceptual framework for designing information barriers that can effectively limit AI systems' ability to interact with their environment in potentially harmful ways
Yampolskiy explores the fundamental limits of AI controllability, providing insights into graduated capability release approaches and their theoretical limitations
Cohen et al. discuss strategic advantage dynamics that highlight the importance of strong capability restriction mechanisms even in soft takeoff scenarios
Kenton et al. examine language agent alignment, with implications for capability control and privilege enforcement mechanisms in language-based AI systems
